 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Employment Agreement with Steve Odland, our Chief Executive Officer in Effect in Fiscal Year 2009
</I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are a party to an Employment Agreement initially dated March&nbsp;11, 2005 as amended as of February&nbsp;25, 2008,
with our Chief Executive Officer, Steve Odland (the above-described &#147;Previous Employment Agreement&#148;). By its terms, the Previous Employment Agreement automatically continues for successive 1-year employment terms ending on each March 11
unless either Mr.&nbsp;Odland or the Company gives at least 90&nbsp;days written notice that the term is not to be extended. Neither the Company nor Mr.&nbsp;Odland has provided notice under the Agreement. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Compensation, Benefits and Perquisites </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Odland is eligible for the following: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">a base salary at the annual rate of at least $1,000,000, subject to annual review and upward adjustment by the Compensation Committee;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">an annual bonus, pursuant to the terms of the Company&#146;s bonus program for executives, with a minimum of 44% of target bonus (or 70% of base
salary) if minimum annual performance targets are met. A &#147;target&#148; level of 160% of base salary applies if target annual performance is met. The annual performance targets are established by the Compensation Committee;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">participation in all long-term equity incentive plans and programs that cover our senior executives, as well as in the welfare benefit plans and
arrangements generally made available to our other senior executives; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">participation in our benefit and &#147;perquisite&#148; programs in effect from time to time for our senior executives, including (i)&nbsp;a $25,000
annual car allowance and (ii)&nbsp;personal use of our corporate aircraft, but such usage is limited to a maximum of 100 hours per calendar year and is subject to income imputation. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a result of the change of control that occurred pursuant to the BC Partners Transaction, all unvested stock options, restricted stock and
other long-term equity or other long-term incentive awards then held by Mr.&nbsp;Odland became fully (100%)&nbsp;vested. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Termination </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s employment may be terminated by the Company or by Mr.&nbsp;Odland at any
time, subject to the terms and condition of his Previous Employment Agreement. The respective rights and obligations of Mr.&nbsp;Odland and the Company depend upon the party that initiates the termination and the reasons for the termination.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table summarizes the termination events (each as defined in Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s Previous Employment
Agreement) and the payments Mr.&nbsp;Odland is eligible to receive upon each event. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

bonus;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"

earned in any of the preceding three completed fiscal years;&nbsp;and</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If any payments would constitute an excess payment under Internal Revenue Code section 280G
and be subject to the excise tax imposed by Internal Revenue Code section 4999 on such excess payments, Mr.&nbsp;Odland is eligible to receive a tax &#147;gross-up&#148; payment of such amount that would leave Mr.&nbsp;Odland in the same tax
position as if no such excise tax (including related penalties or interest) was applicable. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Restrictive Covenants </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the Previous Employment Agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Odland has agreed to various restrictive covenants that can limit certain post-employment
activity. These include a two-year non-competition agreement that bars employment or engaging in any business for any competitor, including office products retailers (other than a business selling office products and supplies as a minor portion of
its business). Other restrictions include non-solicitation and non-interference provisions relating to our employees or employees of any subsidiary, as well as non-solicitation provisions relating to customers, suppliers and other business
relations. In addition, non-disclosure provisions protect our confidential information and work product. Among other remedies, the Company is entitled to cease making payments under Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s Previous Employment Agreement in the event
he violates his post-employment covenants. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Steve Odland&#146;s Amended and Restated Employment Agreement in Effect Beginning February 19,
2010 </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As discussed above, on February 19, 2010, we entered into an Amended and Restated Employment Agreement with
Mr.&nbsp;Odland that amends certain provisions related to severance and change of control arrangements and eliminates tax gross-up benefits contained in the Previous Employment Agreement. The Amended Employment Agreement also provides for the
payment of a cash retention award to Mr. Odland subject to certain conditions. The Amended Employment Agreement became effective on February 19, 2010 for a term ending March 11, 2011, and shall automatically renew for an additional one year period
on each successive March 11 unless the Company or Mr. Odland provides 90 days prior written notice that the term of employment shall not be extended. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table summarizes the termination events (each as defined in Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s Amended Employment Agreement) and the payments Mr.&nbsp;Odland is eligible to receive upon each event.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP> <P STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000;width:65pt"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Termination Event</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP> <P STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000;width:30pt"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Payment</B></FONT></P></TD></TR>


<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-2.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Termination without cause or resignation for good reason</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;accrued compensation and benefits (including accrued, unused vacation
and other benefits);</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a pro rata portion of annual bonus, based on actual performance;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$5 million retention award;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a payment of 24 times
the Company&#146;s monthly COBRA and other welfare benefit plan premiums for the type of coverage in effect for executive on the date of termination, however, in the event of a termination within three years of a change-in-control, payment shall be
for 36 times the Company&#146;s monthly COBRA and other welfare benefit plan premiums for the type of coverage in effect for executive on the date of termination;</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a cash severance payment equal to two times the sum of base salary and
target bonus which amount shall be no less than $5.2 million;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;full and immediate vesting of all time-vested restricted stock, stock options and all other time-vested long-term equity or other long-term incentive awards;&nbsp;and</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the lesser of (i)
24&nbsp;months or (ii) the remaining option term to exercise stock options.</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, in lieu of a tax
gross-up (as was provided under the Previous Employment Agreement) in the event that part or all of the consideration, compensation and benefits to be paid to Mr. Odland pursuant to the Amended Employment Agreement together with the aggregate
present value of payments, consideration, compensation and benefits under all other plans, arrangements and agreements applicable to Mr. Odland would constitute &#147;excess parachute payments&#148; under Section 280G(b) of the Internal Revenue Code
of 1986, as amended (the &#147;Code&#148;), are subject to an excise tax under Section 4999 of the Code (collectively, the &#147;Parachute Amount&#148;), then the amount of excess parachute payments payable under the Amended Employment Agreement
will be reduced if the reduction would result in a greater after-tax amount for Mr. Odland than would occur in such circumstances had he paid the excise tax. If such Parachute Amount is reduced, the reduction in payments shall first be applied to
reduce any cash severance payments and then to reduce other payments and benefits without subjecting Mr. Odland to additional taxation under Section 409A of the Code. The Amended Employment Agreement also eliminates Mr. Odland&#146;s right to a
gross up for additional taxes that could become payable pursuant to 409A of the Code that was included in the Previous Employment Agreement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B><I>Agreements with Chuck Rubin, our President, North American Retail Division </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are a party to an
Executive Employment Agreement initially dated March&nbsp;1, 2004, with Chuck Rubin, who was Executive Vice President Merchandising when the Executive Employment Agreement was initially entered into and who was subsequently named President, North
American Retail in early 2006. The Executive Employment Agreement was amended on June&nbsp;15, 2004, and restated on January&nbsp;23, 2006, in connection with Mr.&nbsp;Rubin&#146;s promotion to his current position of President, North American
Retail. The Executive Employment Agreement was amended and restated effective December&nbsp;31, 2008, to bring the agreement into documentary compliance with Internal Revenue Code section 409A (&#147;Section 409A&#148;). In addition, the Company
entered into a Change of Control Agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Rubin dated March&nbsp;1, 2004, which agreement was amended and restated effective February&nbsp;25, 2008, to bring the agreement into documentary compliance with Section&nbsp;409A.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Executive Employment Agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Rubin </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The term of the Executive Employment Agreement ran until July&nbsp;22, 2009, which period was and will be automatically extended for successive one-year periods unless either Mr.&nbsp;Rubin or we give at
least 6 months prior written notice that the term is not to be extended. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

release of claims against the Company and its affiliates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Restrictive Covenants </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Rubin&#146;s Executive Employment Agreement subjects him to various restrictive covenants that can limit his post-employment
activity. These include an 18-month non-competition period that bars employment or engaging in any business for any competitor. Other restrictions include non-solicitation and non-interference provisions. In addition, non-disclosure provisions
protect our confidential information and work product. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Change of Control Agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Rubin </I></FONT></P> <P

the date of the change of control (as defined in the agreement). If we terminate

Employment Agreement was amended as of July&nbsp;26, 2005, and was amended and restated effective December&nbsp;31, 2008, to bring the agreement into documentary compliance with Section&nbsp;409A. In addition, the Company entered into a Change of

successive one-year periods unless either Mr.&nbsp;Brown or the Company gives at least 6&nbsp;months prior written notice that the term is not to be extended. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT

<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">certain benefits and perquisites. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The substantive provisions of Mr.&nbsp;Brown&#146;s Executive Employment Agreement otherwise accord substantially with those described above for Mr.&nbsp;Rubin except that in the event of termination by
the Company without cause or the resignation of Mr.&nbsp;Brown for good reason, Mr.&nbsp;Brown is not eligible to receive one point five (1.5)&nbsp;times the target bonus, and Mr.&nbsp;Brown&#146;s severance entitlements are not conditioned upon his
execution of a release of claims against the Company and its affiliates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The substantive provisions of the Change of Control
Agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Brown accord with those described above for Mr.&nbsp;Rubin. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

August&nbsp;22, 2008, which was subsequently amended effective December&nbsp;31, 2008, to bring the agreement into documentary compliance with Section&nbsp;409A. We are also a party to a Change of Control Agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Newman dated

post-employment activity. These include an 18-month non-competition period that bars employment or engaging in any business for any competitor. Other restrictions include non-solicitation and non-interference provisions. In addition, non-disclosure
provisions protect our confidential information and work product. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Change of Control Agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Newman </I></FONT></P> <P

except that Mr.&nbsp;Newman is eligible to receive a payment of 18 times the Company&#146;s monthly COBRA premium for the type of coverage in effect for executive on the date of termination. </FONT></P> <P

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Retirement is generally treated as a voluntary termination for all programs except the 2007 Long-Term Incentive Plan, under which all vesting restrictions on stock
options and restricted stock will lapse. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the amount of Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s 2010 target annual bonus prorated for the number of months completed in the bonus period. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prorated bonus assumes actual plan performance is being met. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects a payment equal to the sum of (i)&nbsp;the product of 24 and the monthly COBRA premium on February&nbsp;20, 2010 for the group health plan coverage in effect
for Mr.&nbsp;Odland on February&nbsp;20, 2010, and (ii) the product of 24 and the aggregate monthly premiums on February&nbsp;20, 2010 for the disability, life, accidental death and travel insurance coverage in effect for Mr.&nbsp;Odland on
February&nbsp;20, 2010. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects a payment equal to the sum of (i)&nbsp;two times the sum of Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s base salary in effect for February&nbsp;20, 2010, Mr.&nbsp;Odland&#146;s
2010 target annual bonus which shall be no less than $5.2 million, and (ii)&nbsp;the product of 24 and the monthly COBRA premium on February&nbsp;20, 2010, for the group health plan coverage in effect for Mr.&nbsp;Odland on February&nbsp;20, 2010,
and (iii)&nbsp;the product of 24 and the aggregate monthly premiums for disability insurance, life insurance, accidental death insurance and travel insurance in effect for Mr.&nbsp;Odland on February&nbsp;20, 2010. In the event that such termination
of employment occurs within three years following a change in control, the COBRA premium and insurance premiums shall be determined by substituting &#147;36&#148; for &#147;24&#148;. If &#147;36&#148; were substituted for &#147;24&#148; the cash
severance number would be $5,309,107. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 58 of 82 </FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following tables quantify the potential termination and change of control payment
amounts assuming a hypothetical triggering event had occurred under each of the NEO employment agreements, change of control agreements and equity plans as of December&nbsp;26, 2009. The terms and conditions of the post employment and change of
control provisions for each of the NEOs are described in detail above. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Potential Payments Upon Termination or a Change of
Control </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Charles Brown </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" NOWRAP ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Termination<BR>Resulting<BR>from Death<BR>(a)</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" NOWRAP ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Termination<BR>Resulting<BR>from<BR>Disability</B></FONT><br><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>(b)</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" NOWRAP ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>(1)<BR>Termination<BR>Resulting<BR>from<BR>Retirement<BR>(c)</B></FONT></TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Retirement is generally treated as a voluntary termination for all programs except the 2007 Long-Term Incentive Plan, under which all vesting restrictions on stock
options and restricted stock will lapse. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects Mr.&nbsp;Rubin&#146;s 2009 target annual bonus. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects an amount equal to 1.5 times Mr.&nbsp;Rubin&#146;s target annual bonus. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects an amount equal to the highest annual bonus earned for the 2007, 2008 or 2009 fiscal year. Mr.&nbsp;Rubin&#146;s 2009 bonus represents the highest bonus.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the value of a 24 month outplacement services package. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the value of all unvested stock options based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s stock on December&nbsp;24, 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(7)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the value of all unvested restricted stock based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s stock on December&nbsp;24, 2009. (Vesting occurs upon meeting the
conditions for retirement, not upon actual retirement.) </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(8)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the value of all unvested performance shares based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s stock on December&nbsp;24, 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(9)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects a payment equal to the sum of (i)&nbsp;1.5 times Mr.&nbsp;Rubin&#146;s base salary in effect on December&nbsp;26, 2009, (ii)&nbsp;his 2009 target annual bonus,
(iii)&nbsp;the product of 18 and the monthly COBRA premium on December&nbsp;26, 2009 for the type of group health plan coverage in effect for Mr.&nbsp;Rubin on December&nbsp;26, 2009, and (iv)&nbsp;the product of 18 and the aggregate monthly
premiums on December&nbsp;26, 2009 for the disability insurance, life insurance, accidental death insurance and travel insurance in effect for Mr.&nbsp;Rubin on December&nbsp;26, 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the additional payment (&#147;Gross-up Payment&#148;) that Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt would have received under his Change in Control agreement with the Company to
reimburse him for excise tax under section 4999 of the Internal Revenue Code on excess parachute payments received in connection with a change in control, together with income and FICA taxes on the Gross-up Payment. The Gross-up Payment was
estimated, in accordance with the regulations under section 280G of the Internal Revenue Code without valuing Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt&#146;s non-compete agreement and using the following assumptions: (a)&nbsp;each stock option held by Mr. Schmidt was
canceled on the date of the change in control in exchange for a cash payment equal to a number of option shares times the excess (if any) of the closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on December&nbsp;24, 2009 (i.e., $7.05) over the
exercise price per share for the option and (b)&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt will pay tax on additional compensation and excess parachute payments at the following rates: federal income tax, 35%; state and local income tax, 0%; FICA tax, 1.45% (Medicare
only); parachute excise tax, 20%. The Gross-up Payment increases the total excess parachute payments by an equal amount. Note that if Mr. Schmidt&#146;s stock options had remained outstanding and exercisable after the change in control, the value of
the options characterized as parachute payments, and consequently the amount of the Gross-up Payment would have been larger. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(7)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the value of all unvested stock options based on the closing price of the Company&#146;s stock on December&nbsp;24, 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

Executive was not employed by the Company for the whole of such fiscal year) Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt&#146;s highest bonus was earned in 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(12)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As noted previously in &#147;Summary of Executive Agreements and Potential Payments upon Termination or Change in Control&#148; above, Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt does not have a
formal employment agreement but has an offer letter that articulated certain severance benefits. Effective December 4, 2008 Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt and the Company entered into a Change in Control agreement. The information reflected in this chart is in
accordance with the terms of that offer letter and change in control agreement. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(13)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects an amount equal to (i)&nbsp;two times the sum of Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt&#146;s annual base salary (including car allowance) in effect on December&nbsp;26, 2009, and
Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt&#146;s highest bonus earned with respect to the 2007, 2008 and 2009 fiscal year, and (ii)&nbsp;the product of 18 and the monthly COBRA premium on December&nbsp;26, 2009 for the type of group health plan coverage in effect for
Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt on December&nbsp;26, 2009. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(14)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The vesting of restricted stock and performance shares is triggered by the change in control. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(15)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If termination due to death or disability occurs after the change in control, Mr.&nbsp;Schmidt is entitled to all amounts in this column other than outplacement
services and COBRA premiums. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)</FONT></TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Reflects the additional payment (&#147;Gross-up Payment&#148;) that Mr.&nbsp;Newman would have received under his Change in Control agreement with the Company to
reimburse him for excise tax under section 4999 of the Internal Revenue Code on excess parachute payments received in connection with a change in control, together with income and FICA taxes on the Gross-up Payment. The Gross-up Payment was
estimated, in accordance with the regulations under section 280G of the Internal Revenue Code without valuing Mr.&nbsp;Newman&#146;s non-compete agreement and using the following assumptions: (a)&nbsp;each stock option held by Mr. Newman was
canceled on the date of the change in control in exchange for a cash payment equal to a number of option shares times the excess (if any) of the closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on December&nbsp;24, 2009 (i.e., $7.05) over the
exercise price per share for the option and (b)&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Newman will pay tax on additional compensation and excess parachute payments at the following rates: federal income tax, 35%; state and local income tax, 0%; FICA tax, 1.45% (Medicare
only); parachute excise tax, 20%. The Gross-up Payment increases the total excess parachute payments by an equal amount. Note that if Mr. Newman&#146;s stock options had remained outstanding and exercisable after the change in control, the value of
the options characterized as parachute payments, and consequently the amount of the Gross-up Payment would have been larger. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="line-height:8px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000;width:10%">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Includes shares of common stock subject to options exercisable within 60&nbsp;days of March 3, 2010, even though a considerable number of the options are underwater.
See &#147;Options Exercisable within 60 days of Record Date&#148; table below for detail. Also included are unvested shares of restricted stock, as to which the holder has voting rights. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Applicable percentage of ownership for all shareholders listed in the table above except for BC Partners Holdings, Ltd. and related entities (including CIE Management
II Limited and LMBO Europe SAS) is based on 274,730,666 shares of common stock outstanding as of March&nbsp;3, 2010 together with the exercisable stock options, for such shareholder or group of shareholders, as&nbsp;applicable.&nbsp;Applicable
percentage of ownership for BC Partners Holdings, Ltd. (including CIE Management II Limited and LMBO Europe SAS) is based on 348,433,860 shares of common stock, which includes the as-converted number of common shares underlying the shares of Series
B Preferred owned by these entities, which are now convertible into common stock. In computing the number of shares of common stock beneficially owned by a person and the percentage ownership of that person, shares issuable upon the exercise of
options that are exercisable within 60 days of March&nbsp;3, 2010 are not deemed outstanding for purposes of computing the percentage of ownership of any other person. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The information regarding CIE Management II Limited, which we refer to as CIE, and LMBO Europe SAS, which we refer to as LMBO, is as of July&nbsp;2, 2009 and was
derived from a Schedule 13D filed jointly by (i)&nbsp;BC European Capital VIII-1 to 12 (inclusive), each a United Kingdom limited partnership (&#147;Funds 1-12&#148;); (ii)&nbsp;BC European Capital VIII-14 to 34 (inclusive), each a United Kingdom
limited partnership (&#147;Funds 14-34&#148; and together with Funds 1-12, the &#147;CIE Investors&#148;); (iii)&nbsp;BC European Capital VIII-35 SC to 39 SC (inclusive), each a Soci&eacute;t&eacute; Civiles organized under the laws of France (the
&#147;LMBO Investors&#148; and together with the CIE Investors, the &#147;Investors&#148;); (iv)&nbsp;LMBO; and (v)&nbsp;CIE on July&nbsp;2, 2009. CIE is the general partner of, and has investment control over the shares held by, each of the CIE
Investors and LMBO is G&eacute;rant as to, and has investment control over the shares held by, each of the LMBO Investors. BC Partners Holdings Limited, a limited corporation organized under the laws of Guernsey, Channel Islands (&#147;BCHL&#148;),
is the controlling entity of each of (i)&nbsp;CIE; and (ii)&nbsp;LMBO. CIE, LMBO and BCHL are each managed by separate boards of directors. A list of the directors of CIE, LMBO and BCHL is provided on Schedules II, III and IV to the Schedule 13D
filed on July&nbsp;2, 2009 and none of those directors have beneficial ownership of the share held by the Investors. Since CIE, LMBO and BCHL are managed by boards of directors, no individuals have ultimate voting or investment control (as
determined by Rule 13d-3) over the shares that may be deemed beneficially owned by CIE and LMBO. We have no further information or knowledge about CIE, LMBO or BCHL. The Investors, CIE and LMBO may be deemed to be a &#147;group&#148; (within the
meaning of Section&nbsp;13(d)(3) of the Securities Exchange Act) and, as such, may be deemed to be beneficial owners of (y)&nbsp;274,596 shares of 10% Series A Redeemable Convertible Participating Perpetual Preferred Stock, par value $0.01 per share
and (z)&nbsp;75,404 shares of 10% Series B Redeemable Conditional Convertible Participating Perpetual Preferred Stock, par value $0.01 per share, of Office Depot, Inc., each Investor, however, disclaims beneficial ownership with respect to the
shares owned by each of the other Investors, CIE and LMBO. None of the Investors own any shares of common stock over which it has sole voting, disposition or investment power. The figures in the table set forth the number of shares of common stock,
on an as-converted basis, owned of record and beneficially owned by the funds including the as-converted underlying shares of Series B Preferred owned by the funds, which are now convertible into common stock. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)</FONT></TD>

Schedule 13G/A filed on February&nbsp;16, 2010 by Samana Capital, L.P. (&#147;SC&#148;), Morton Holdings, Inc. (&#147;MH&#148;), and Philip B. Korsant. Partnerships of which MH is the general partner, including SC, are the owners of record. Each of
MH and Philip B Korsant may be deemed to beneficially own the shares reported herein as a result of the direct or indirect power to vote or dispose of such shares. SC reported shared voting power over 18,045,546 shares and shared dispositive power
over 18,045,546. MH and Philip B. Korsant reported shared voting power over 22,622,844 shares and shared dispositive power over 22,622,844 shares. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">0</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">* * * </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="tx29639_43"></A>Item&nbsp;2: Ratifying Our Audit Committee&#146;s Appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP as Our
Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I><A NAME="tx29639_44"></A>Information About Our Independent Registered Public
Accounting Firm </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In accordance with the provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (&#147;SOA&#148;), the Audit
Committee of our Board of Directors appointed the certified public accounting firm of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP (&#147;Deloitte&#148;) as our independent registered public accounting firm to audit our consolidated financial statements and our
internal control over financial reporting for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;26, 2009 and to issue an opinion on management&#146;s report on internal control over financial reporting. Deloitte has audited our consolidated financial statements
each year since 1990. Representatives of Deloitte will be present at our Annual Meeting with the opportunity to make a statement if they desire to do so, and they will be available to respond to appropriate questions from shareholders. Our Audit
Committee also has appointed Deloitte as our independent registered public accounting firm for 2010. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 69 of 82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Although our Audit Committee already has appointed Deloitte as our independent registered
public accounting firm for 2010 and the vote of our shareholders is not required for this action under Delaware law or the SOA, we request that the shareholders nevertheless ratify this appointment. As a matter of good corporate governance, we are
submitting this item for shareholder approval. In the event the we do not receive the required vote the Audit Committee will consider such vote when appointing our independent registered public accounting firm for 2011. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I><A NAME="tx29639_45"></A>Audit&nbsp;&amp; Other Fees </I></B> </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The fees for our independent registered public accounting firm for professional services rendered in connection with (i)&nbsp;the audit of our annual financial statements as set forth in our Annual Report
on Form&nbsp;10-K for the fiscal years ended December&nbsp;27, 2008 and December&nbsp;26, 2009, (ii)&nbsp;the review of our quarterly financial statements as set forth in our Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for each of our fiscal quarters during
2008 and 2009, and (iii)&nbsp;the audit of our internal control over financial reporting with the objective of obtaining reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects,
as well as fees paid to our independent registered public accounting firm for audit-related work, tax compliance, tax planning and other consulting services are set forth below. </FONT></P> <P

</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Audit Fees</B>&#151;Consists of fees for professional services rendered in connection with the audits of
our consolidated financial statements and the effectiveness of our internal controls over financial reporting for the fiscal years ended December&nbsp;26, 2009 and December&nbsp;27, 2008; the reviews of the consolidated financial statements included
in each of our Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q during those fiscal years; consultations on accounting matters; statutory audit filings; and SEC registration statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Audit Related Fees</B>&#151;Consists primarily of assurance related fees associated with International business restructuring, tax system implementation review and fees for acquisition-related due
diligence activities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Tax Fees</B>&#151;Consists primarily of fees for tax compliance. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>All Other Fees</B>&#151;Consists of fees for all other services not included above, principally advisory services and tax planning.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Audit Committee Pre-Approval Policies and Procedures </I></B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee has established policies and procedures under which audit and non-audit services performed by the Company&#146;s
independent registered public accounting firm must be approved in advance by the Audit Committee. The Audit Committee&#146;s policy provides for pre-approval of audit, audit-related, tax and other
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 70 of 82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
services specifically described by the Audit Committee on an annual basis. In addition, individual engagements anticipated to exceed pre-established thresholds, as well as any other services,
must be separately approved. The policy also provides that the Audit Committee has delegated pre-approval authority to the Chair of the Audit Committee provided that the pre-approval of any matters permitted by the Chair is reported to the full
Audit Committee at its next meeting. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I><A NAME="tx29639_46"></A>Financial Information Systems Design and Implementation Fees </I></B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We did not engage Deloitte to provide any professional services in connection with (i)&nbsp;operating or supervising the
operation of our information system or managing our local area network; or (ii)&nbsp;designing or implementing a hardware or software system that aggregates source data underlying the financial statements or generates information that is significant
to the Company&#146;s financial statements taken as a whole. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I><A NAME="tx29639_47"></A>Independence </I></B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee of our Board of Directors has determined that the non-audit services rendered by our independent registered public
accounting firm during our most recent fiscal year are compatible with maintaining their independence. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Your Audit Committee
of the Board of Directors Recommends a Vote&nbsp;FOR Item&nbsp;2 on Your </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Proxy Card: </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Ratification of Our Audit Committee&#146;s Appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP as our </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="tx29639_48"></A>AUDIT COMMITTEE REPORT </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>The following Report
of the Audit Committee does not constitute soliciting material and should not be deemed filed or incorporated by reference into any other Company filing under the Securities Act of 1933 or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, except to the extent
the Company specifically incorporates this Report by reference therein. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee of the Office Depot Board of
Directors (the &#147;Committee&#148;) is comprised of four Independent Directors. The responsibilities of the Committee are set forth in its written charter (the &#147;Charter&#148;), which has been adopted by our Board of Directors. A copy of the
Charter may be obtained from our Company in the manner described elsewhere in this Proxy Statement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The duties of this
Committee include oversight of the financial reporting process for the Company through periodic meetings with the Company&#146;s independent accountants, internal auditors and management of the Company to review accounting, auditing, internal
controls and financial reporting matters. Pursuant to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (&#147;SOA&#148;), our Committee has certain other duties, which include the engagement of our independent registered public accounting firm, Deloitte&nbsp;&amp;
Touche LLP (&#147;Deloitte&#148;), pre-approval of both audit and non-audit work in advance of Deloitte&#146;s commencing such work and other obligations as imposed by SOA. Pursuant to applicable provisions of SOA, we have delegated to the Chair the
authority to pre-approve engagements of Deloitte between meetings of our Committee, provided that she reports to us at each meeting on pre-approvals since the date of our last Committee meeting. Our Board of Directors has determined that the
following members of our Audit Committee are &#147;audit committee financial experts&#148; under the regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission promulgated pursuant to authority granted to it under SOA: Ms.&nbsp;Gaines, Ms.&nbsp;Mason and
Mr.&nbsp;Colligan(1). These persons&#146; qualifications are detailed in their biographical information set forth earlier in this Proxy Statement. In addition, in accordance with listing standards of the New York Stock Exchange, our Board of
Directors has determined that each member of our Audit Committee is financially literate as required by such listing standards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 71 of 82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During fiscal year 2009 this Committee met five (5)&nbsp;times, which included meetings to
discuss quarterly or annual earnings press releases in advance of release by the Company. The Company&#146;s senior financial management and independent and internal auditors were in attendance at all such meetings. At each such meeting, this
Committee conducted a private session with the management of our Internal Audit Department as well as Deloitte, without the presence of management. In addition, our Audit Committee conducted private sessions at various meetings during 2009 with our
Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Controller and General Counsel. In addition, our Audit Committee received periodic reports from the Company&#146;s Disclosure Committee which reviews the Company&#146;s disclosures and ensures that
effective controls and procedures are in place related to the Company&#146;s disclosures. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The management of the Company is
responsible for the preparation and integrity of the financial reporting information and related systems of internal controls. The Audit Committee, in carrying out its role, relies on the Company&#146;s senior management, including particularly its
senior financial management, to prepare financial statements with integrity and objectivity and in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and relies upon the Company&#146;s independent accountants to review or audit, as
applicable, such financial statements in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have reviewed and
discussed with senior management the Company&#146;s audited financial statements for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;26, 2009, included in the Company&#146;s 2009 Annual Report on Form 10-K. Management has confirmed to us that such financial
statements (i)&nbsp;have been prepared with integrity and objectivity and are the responsibility of management and (ii)&nbsp;have been prepared in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In discharging our oversight responsibility as to the audit process, we have reviewed and discussed with management and Deloitte, the
Company&#146;s audited consolidated financial statements and the Company&#146;s internal controls over financial reporting. We have also discussed with Deloitte the matters required to be discussed by Statement on Auditing Standards No.&nbsp;114
(&#147;SAS 114&#148;&#151;The Auditor&#146;s Communication with those Charged with Governance). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have obtained the written
disclosures and the letter from Deloitte required by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board including but not limited to the disclosures required by Independence Standards Board of Directors Standard No.&nbsp;1 (Independence Discussion with
Audit Committees) with respect to any relationship between Deloitte and the Company that in its professional judgment may reasonably be thought to bear on independence. Deloitte has discussed its independence with us, and has confirmed in its letter
to us that, in its professional judgment, it is independent of the Company within the meaning of the United States securities laws. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Based upon the foregoing review and discussions with our independent and internal auditors and senior management of the Company, we have recommended to our Board of Directors that the financial statements prepared by the Company&#146;s
management and audited by its independent accountants be included in the Company&#146;s 2009 Annual Report on Form 10-K for filing with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. The Committee also has appointed Deloitte as the
Company&#146;s independent accounting firm for 2010. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As specified in the Charter, it is not the duty of this Committee to
plan or conduct audits or to determine that the Company&#146;s financial statements are complete and accurate and prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. These are the responsibilities of the Company&#146;s management,
internal auditors and independent accountants. In discharging our duties as a Committee, we have relied on (i)&nbsp;management&#146;s representations to us that the financial statements prepared by management have been prepared with integrity and
objectivity and in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles and (ii)&nbsp;the report of the Company&#146;s independent accountants with respect to such financial statements. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 72 of 82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1) Mr.&nbsp;Colligan joined the Audit Committee in January, 2010 and did not participate in
the review and discussion of this Report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Presented by the members of the Audit Committee as of Fiscal Year Ended 2009:
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Brenda J. Gaines (Chair) </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Myra M. Hart </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Kathleen Mason </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">* * * </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="tx29639_49">
</A>Item&nbsp;3: Approval of an Amendment to Our Amended Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan and Implementation of a Stock Option Exchange Program for Eligible Employees </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are seeking shareholder approval of an amendment to Office Depot&#146;s Amended Long-Term Incentive Plan (the &#147;Incentive Plan&#148;) to allow for a one-time stock option exchange program (the
&#147;Exchange Program&#148;). If implemented, the Exchange Program will allow us to cancel certain outstanding stock options issued under the Incentive Plan and the Office Depot 2007 Long-Term Incentive Plan (the &#147;2007 Plan&#148;) currently
held by some of our employees in exchange for the grant of a lesser amount of stock options with exercise prices equal to fair market value on the date of grant. The exchange ratio will be designed to result in the grant of new stock options with a
value approximately equal to, but no higher than, the value of the options that are surrendered. We will use the higher of the 52-week high closing price of our common stock or 50% above the current stock price (measured at the commencement of the
Exchange Program) as a threshold for options eligible to be exchanged. The use of this threshold is designed to ensure that only outstanding options that are significantly &#147;underwater&#148; (meaning the exercise prices of the options are
greater than our current stock price) are eligible for the Exchange Program. In addition, only stock options that were granted at least 12 months prior to the commencement of the exchange offer and have an exercise price of $11.00 or greater will be
eligible for exchange under the Exchange Program. Stock options whose term will expire before the expiration of the exchange period will not be eligible for exchange under the Exchange Program. The members of the Board of Directors and our named
executive officers will not be eligible to participate in the Exchange Program. In addition, the Exchange Program will not be offered to retirees or other former employees of the Company or employees located in countries where we determine that it
is neither practical nor desirable to offer the Exchange Program. Shareholder approval is required for this proposal under the NYSE listing rules and the terms of the 2007 Plan. If our shareholders approve the amendment to the Incentive Plan and the
implementation of the Exchange Program, we intend to commence the Exchange Program promptly after shareholder approval is obtained. However we may defer commencement of the Exchange Program until December&nbsp;31, 2010. If our shareholders do not
approve this proposal, the Exchange Program will not take place. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Overview </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our stock price has experienced a significant decline during the last few years due in large part to the continued weak economy as well as
the adverse impact on our customers from extreme volatility in the stock market, a systematic lack of liquidity and deep cuts in corporate spending. Like many retailers, our business has been, and continues to be, adversely impacted by the global
financial and economic crises. We have taken a number of actions in the past few years to transform and reinvigorate our business and improve our performance. We have increased our liquidity by over $500 million during 2009, closed over 150 poorly
performing retail stores in North America and Asia, closed 12 distribution centers in North America and Europe, rationalized underperforming businesses, began integrating two North American supply chain systems, developed innovative new private
branded products, worked closely with our global vendor partners and engaged and retained our talented associates worldwide. While our efforts have had a positive impact on our corporate performance, our stock price still remains at a relatively low
level compared to historic highs. Consequently, certain of our employees hold stock options with exercise prices that greatly exceed both the current market price of our
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 73 of 82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
common stock and the average market price of our stock over the prior 12&nbsp;months. Further, there can be no assurance that our efforts to transform and reinvigorate our business and improve
our performance will ultimately result in our underwater options having any value before they expire. The Board of Directors believes these underwater options no longer provide the long-term incentive and retention objectives that they were intended
to provide. The Board of Directors believes the Exchange Program is an important component in our strategy to align employee and shareholder interests through our equity compensation programs. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On February 17, 2010, our Board of Directors, at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, which is comprised entirely of
independent directors, determined that, to assist in the retention and motivation of key employees, it would be in the best interest of the Company and its shareholders to implement the Exchange Program, subject to approval by shareholders. If
approved by shareholders, certain current employees holding outstanding stock options issued under the 2007 Incentive Plan and the Incentive Plan that have an exercise price above the higher of the 52-week high closing price of our common stock or
50% above the current stock price at the commencement of the Exchange Program (which, as of March 3, 2010, was $10.89 which is 50% above our stock price on the NYSE on that day of $7.26) (the &#147;Eligible Employees&#148;) would be eligible to
exchange their outstanding stock options for new stock options intended to be of equivalent value but covering significantly fewer shares. In addition, only stock options that were granted at least 12 months prior to the commencement of the exchange
offer and have an exercise price of $11.00 or greater will be eligible for exchange under the Exchange Program. Stock options whose term will expire before the expiration of the exchange period will not be eligible for exchange under the Exchange
Program. The Company&#146;s directors and named executive officers will not be eligible to participate in the Exchange Program. In addition, the Exchange Program will not be offered to retirees or other former employees of the Company or employees
located in countries where we determine that it is neither practical nor desirable to offer the Exchange Program. On March 3, 2010, all stock options held by Eligible Employees consisted of stock options to purchase 11.9 million shares of the
Company&#146;s common stock with exercise prices ranging from $0.85 to $41.25 per share, or approximately 0.12 to more than 5.68 times above the closing market price per share on the NYSE on that day of $7.26. Approximately 42% of our outstanding
options held by Eligible Employees are underwater (the exercise price is higher than our current stock price). While the weighted average years remaining until expiration for these underwater stock options is approximately 3.5 years, the
Compensation Committee and our Board of Directors believes it is critical to implement this Exchange Program at this time in order to be able to continue to retain and motivate key employees, particularly given the challenges and difficult operating
conditions which currently persist in the industry. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to aiding the Company and its subsidiaries in the retention
and motivation of our employees, we believe that the Exchange Program would be beneficial to shareholders by resulting in the cancellation of a large number of outstanding stock options and the issuance of new stock options for significantly fewer
shares in their place. In addition, by conducting the Exchange Program rather than the alternative of granting additional new awards to supplement the out-of-the money stock options, we are avoiding potential additional dilution to our
shareholders&#146; interests and significant financial expense. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">When considering how best to continue to incentivize and
reward our employees who have underwater options, we considered the following alternatives: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Increase cash
compensation.</I>&nbsp;To replace equity incentives, we considered whether we could substantially increase base and target bonus cash compensation. However, significant increases in cash compensation would substantially increase our compensation
expense and reduce our cash flow from operations, which could adversely affect our business and operating results. In addition, these increases would not reduce our overhang or promote retention. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Grant additional stock options.</I>&nbsp;We also considered special grants of additional stock options at current market prices or
another form of equity award such as restricted stock units. However, these additional grants would substantially increase our overhang, the dilution to our shareholders and our compensation expense. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Page 74 of 82 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Exchange options for cash.</I>&nbsp;We also considered implementing a program to exchange
underwater options for cash payments. However, an exchange program for cash would have an adverse cash impact and reduce our cash flow from operations, which could adversely affect our business and operating results. In addition, we do not believe
that such a program would have significant long-term retention value. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Exchange options for restricted stock
units.</I>&nbsp;We also considered implementing a program to exchange underwater options for restricted stock units. However, this transfers shareholder value to the grantees even if future performance for the price of our common stock is flat or
negative. Consequently, we do not think this appropriately aligns the grantees&#146; interests with the shareholders&#146; interests. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Do nothing.</I> If we opted to do nothing with our currently outstanding stock options, there would be no benefit to us for the expense recognized related to the unvested options, and with little hope of value, they would not be
effective tools for compensating, motivating and retaining our employees. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Exchange Program has been designed to include
the following, which we believe will address concerns often expressed by shareholders and reflect best market practices: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Exchange Program will apply only to stock options that have an exercise price above the higher of the 52-week high closing price of our common
stock or 50% above the current stock price at the commencement of the Exchange Program (which, as of March 3, 2010, was $10.89); </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Only stock options that were granted at least 12 months prior to the commencement of the exchange offer and have an exercise price of $11.00 or greater
will be eligible for exchange under the Exchange Program; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stock options whose term will expire before the expiration of the exchange period will not be eligible for exchange under the Exchange Program;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Employees who hold 1,000 or fewer Eligible Options, will be eligible to participate in the Exchange Program however instead of receiving New Stock
Options, these employees will receive cash, not subject to vesting requirements, in an amount calculated in accordance with the option valuation method described below; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Exchange ratio will be calculated so that the new options received in the Exchange Program will have a value approximately equal to the value
(established in accordance with the option valuation method described below) of the exchanged stock options; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The new stock options issued in exchange for outstanding vested or unvested stock options will vest over a three-year period with one-third
(1/3)&nbsp;vesting on the first anniversary of the date of grant and one-third (1/3)&nbsp;on each of the next two successive anniversaries; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
